part.partText: with thin-walled skin (< 1 mm); surface tan, covered with tiny, brown, flat scales. When mature it opens by a pore at the top.
firm to hard when young, may be whitish but is soon purplish gray; when mature the spore mass is dark brown and powdery.
short, stem-like, typically has branched, whitish cords that bind to the soil.
Spores 10 - 18 µm (including spines), brown, surface spiny but not reticulate.

similarSpecies.comments: This species differs from our other scaly Scleroderma species by the small size of the fruitbody, the thin wall, and the spores. Scleroderma verrucosum differs by having spores 7 - 11.6 µm. True puffballs, such as Lycoperdon, have a thinner outer skin and a pure white inside when young. Lycoperdon pyriforme has white cords at the base but grows on wood and has smooth spores.

speciesPage.fruiting: July to September; rarely June or October.
speciesPage.habitatEcology: Common in hardwood forest, oak woodland, and oak savanna. Solitary or gregarious on soil or wood. Mycorrhizal partner with oak (and possibly other hosts) in our region.

notes.comments: Sclerodermas are called earthballs or false puffballs and are related to boletes. This small Scleroderma species was also named S. lycoperdoides because it resembles a Lycoperdon (a true puffball).

etymology.comments: "Sclero-derma" means "hard-skin." Areolate refers to having a small area, as in a ring of color around each scale.
